Urban Development Minister M. Venkaiah Naidu along with Secretary Madhusudan Prasad (left) and Principal Director-General of Media and Communication, Frank Naronha (right), showing the list of winners of the first round of ‘Smart City Challenge Competition,’ inNew Delhi on Thursday.- Photo: Shanker Chakravarty

The aim was to inform them that the project cuts out aggressive State spending and municipalities have to generate funds from private investors and take capacity-building measures to initiate big projects.

In response to months-long criticism over the government’s inability to define a smart city, Mr. Naidu said that in an Indian context it is a city that “enables a decent life to the citizens and green and sustainable environment besides enabling adoption of smart solutions.”

“It [smart city] cannot be made overnight,” said Mr. Naidu, “but the beginning has been made.”

The success of the government’s Smart City Mission is largely dependent upon the finance generation at the State-level as well as private investments.

The Centre has set aside Rs. 50,802 crore for the mission and the money will be released to urban local bodies at frequent intervals in the next five years. The Centre has asked the State governments to generate the rest of the amount as the grand total of the mission is estimated at Rs.101604 crore.

‘It cannot be made overnight, but a beginning has been made, says Venkaiah Naidu
title: 20 smart cities chosen
